Regexes can be wildly different in their performance characteristics 
with just a single character difference; you may want to profile and 
optimize your regexes.

Also, long lists of regexes to apply in sequence can be costly for 
ruling things in or out; that's why we try to use simpler 
prefix-matching whenever possible.

We've had crawls on relatively modest machines (2 cores, ~4GB RAM, 4 
disks) that collect 150-200 URIs/sec at initial launch but then settle 
to 30-60 URIs/sec after days or weeks of running.

What you might get depends a lot on your system specs, and the general 
'shape'/settings of your crawl. Tweaking the settings can make a big 
difference, and there's also a lot more room for optimization in the 
code if any team needed to really squeeze the most out of a small 
hardware budget. (We have often chosen 'more machines' over 'more coding 
optimizations' when we need greater throughput.)

- Gordon @ IA
